title: Machine Learning Fundamentals
description: Test your knowledge of core machine learning concepts, algorithms, and terminology.

questions.question: What is the primary goal of machine learning?
options: To create programs that can think like humans
To enable computers to learn from data without being explicitly programmed
To replace all human jobs with automation
questions.correctAnswer: To enable computers to learn from data without being explicitly programmed
questions.explanation: Machine learning focuses on algorithms that can learn patterns from data and make predictions or decisions without being explicitly programmed for each specific task.

questions.question: In supervised learning, the training data includes:
options: Both input features and corresponding output labels
Only output labels without input features
questions.correctAnswer: Both input features and corresponding output labels
questions.explanation: Supervised learning algorithms learn from labeled training data where each example has both input features and the correct output (label).

questions.question: Linear regression is primarily used for:
questions.correctAnswer: Predicting continuous numerical values
questions.explanation: Linear regression predicts continuous output values by finding the best linear relationship between input features and the target variable.

questions.question: What is overfitting in machine learning?
options: When the model performs well on training data but poorly on new data
When the model is too simple to capture the underlying patterns
When the training takes too long to complete
When the model has too many features
questions.correctAnswer: When the model performs well on training data but poorly on new data
questions.explanation: Overfitting occurs when a model learns the training data too well, including noise and outliers, making it perform poorly on unseen data.

questions.question: What makes neural networks different from traditional machine learning algorithms?
options: They can automatically learn hierarchical features from raw data
They only work with categorical data
They are much slower than traditional algorithms
questions.correctAnswer: They can automatically learn hierarchical features from raw data
questions.explanation: Neural networks can learn complex hierarchical representations directly from raw input data through multiple layers of processing.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of gradient descent in machine learning?
options: To minimize the loss function by iteratively adjusting model parameters
To split the dataset into training and testing sets
questions.correctAnswer: To minimize the loss function by iteratively adjusting model parameters
questions.explanation: Gradient descent is an optimization algorithm that finds the minimum of a loss function by taking steps proportional to the negative gradient.

questions.question: In a confusion matrix for binary classification, what does the term 'recall' represent?
options: The proportion of true positives among all positive predictions
The proportion of true positives among all actual positive cases
The proportion of correct predictions among all predictions
The proportion of negative predictions that are correct
questions.correctAnswer: The proportion of true positives among all actual positive cases
questions.explanation: Recall (also called sensitivity or true positive rate) measures the ability of a model to find all the relevant cases within a dataset.

questions.question: Why is feature scaling important in many machine learning algorithms?
options: To reduce the number of features
To ensure all features contribute equally to the distance calculations
To convert categorical features to numerical
To handle missing values in the dataset
questions.correctAnswer: To ensure all features contribute equally to the distance calculations
questions.explanation: Feature scaling ensures that features with different scales (e.g., age in years vs. income in dollars) don't dominate the learning process.

questions.question: What is the main benefit of k-fold cross-validation?
options: It provides a more reliable estimate of model performance on unseen data
It automatically selects the best hyperparameters
It eliminates the need for a separate test set
questions.correctAnswer: It provides a more reliable estimate of model performance on unseen data
questions.explanation: Cross-validation helps assess how well a model will generalize to new data by testing it on multiple subsets of the available data.

questions.question: What type of regularization adds a penalty equal to the square of the magnitude of coefficients?
questions.correctAnswer: L2 regularization (Ridge)
questions.explanation: L2 regularization adds a penalty term proportional to the square of the coefficients, which helps prevent overfitting by shrinking coefficients towards zero.

title: Deep Learning Fundamentals
description: Explore neural networks, activation functions, and deep learning architectures.

questions.question: Which activation function is commonly used in the output layer for binary classification?
questions.correctAnswer: Sigmoid
questions.explanation: Sigmoid activation function outputs values between 0 and 1, making it suitable for binary classification probabilities.

questions.question: What is the primary advantage of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) over regular neural networks for image processing?
options: They automatically learn spatial hierarchies of features
They are much faster to train
questions.correctAnswer: They automatically learn spatial hierarchies of features
questions.explanation: CNNs use convolutional layers that learn spatial patterns and hierarchies, making them highly effective for image recognition tasks.

questions.question: What is the purpose of backpropagation in neural networks?
options: To compute the forward pass through the network
To calculate gradients and update weights during training
questions.correctAnswer: To calculate gradients and update weights during training
questions.explanation: Backpropagation computes the gradient of the loss function with respect to each weight by propagating errors backward through the network.

questions.question: What problem occurs when training very deep neural networks with sigmoid activation functions?
questions.correctAnswer: Vanishing gradients
questions.explanation: The vanishing gradient problem occurs when gradients become extremely small during backpropagation, preventing the network from learning effectively.

questions.question: What is the main benefit of batch normalization in neural networks?
options: It reduces the number of parameters
It stabilizes and accelerates training by normalizing layer inputs
questions.correctAnswer: It stabilizes and accelerates training by normalizing layer inputs
questions.explanation: Batch normalization normalizes the inputs to each layer, reducing internal covariate shift and allowing for higher learning rates.

title: Data Preprocessing
description: Learn about data cleaning, feature engineering, and preparing data for machine learning.

questions.question: What is data preprocessing in machine learning?
options: The process of preparing and cleaning raw data for modeling
questions.correctAnswer: The process of preparing and cleaning raw data for modeling
questions.explanation: Data preprocessing involves cleaning, transforming, and organizing raw data into a format suitable for machine learning algorithms.

questions.question: Which technique is used to handle missing values by replacing them with the mean?
questions.correctAnswer: Imputation
questions.explanation: Imputation replaces missing values with statistical measures like mean, median, or mode, or uses more advanced techniques like KNN imputation.

questions.question: What is one-hot encoding used for?
options: Converting categorical variables to numerical format
questions.correctAnswer: Converting categorical variables to numerical format
questions.explanation: One-hot encoding creates binary columns for each category, allowing categorical variables to be used in machine learning algorithms.

questions.question: What is the purpose of train-test split?
options: To evaluate model performance on unseen data
To make the model more complex
questions.correctAnswer: To evaluate model performance on unseen data
questions.explanation: Train-test split divides data into training and testing sets, allowing evaluation of model generalization on unseen data.

questions.question: What does feature scaling do?
options: Changes the scale/range of numerical features
questions.correctAnswer: Changes the scale/range of numerical features
questions.explanation: Feature scaling normalizes or standardizes numerical features to bring them to a similar scale, preventing features with larger ranges from dominating.

questions.question: What is outlier detection used for?
options: To find the best model parameters
To identify data points that deviate significantly from the norm
questions.correctAnswer: To identify data points that deviate significantly from the norm
questions.explanation: Outlier detection identifies unusual data points that may be errors or represent rare events, which can affect model performance.

questions.question: What is data normalization?
options: Scaling features to a standard normal distribution
questions.correctAnswer: Scaling features to a standard normal distribution
questions.explanation: Normalization scales features to have a mean of 0 and standard deviation of 1, following a standard normal distribution.

questions.question: What is feature engineering?
options: Creating new features from existing data
questions.correctAnswer: Creating new features from existing data
questions.explanation: Feature engineering involves creating new features, transforming existing ones, or selecting the most relevant features to improve model performance.

title: Model Evaluation & Validation
description: Understand how to evaluate and validate machine learning models.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a confusion matrix?
options: To show the performance of a classification model
questions.correctAnswer: To show the performance of a classification model
questions.explanation: A confusion matrix shows the number of correct and incorrect predictions, broken down by each class.

questions.question: What does precision measure in classification?
options: The proportion of actual positives correctly identified
The proportion of predicted positives that are actually positive
The proportion of negative predictions that are correct
The overall accuracy of the model
questions.correctAnswer: The proportion of predicted positives that are actually positive
questions.explanation: Precision measures how many of the predicted positive cases are actually positive, focusing on the quality of positive predictions.

questions.question: What is F1-score?
options: The harmonic mean of precision and recall
questions.correctAnswer: The harmonic mean of precision and recall
questions.explanation: F1-score is the harmonic mean of precision and recall, providing a balanced measure of classification performance.

questions.question: What is ROC curve used for?
options: Visualizing the trade-off between true positive rate and false positive rate
questions.correctAnswer: Visualizing the trade-off between true positive rate and false positive rate
questions.explanation: ROC curve plots the true positive rate against the false positive rate at different classification thresholds.

questions.question: What does AUC stand for in the context of ROC curves?
questions.correctAnswer: Area Under Curve
questions.explanation: AUC (Area Under Curve) measures the area under the ROC curve, providing a single metric for model performance.

questions.question: What is mean squared error (MSE) used to evaluate?
questions.correctAnswer: Regression models
questions.explanation: MSE measures the average squared difference between predicted and actual values in regression problems.

questions.question: What is R-squared (RÂ²) in regression?
options: The proportion of variance explained by the model
questions.correctAnswer: The proportion of variance explained by the model
questions.explanation: R-squared measures how well the regression model explains the variability of the response data.

questions.question: What is cross-validation?
options: A method to train models faster
A technique to evaluate model performance on multiple data splits
A way to reduce model complexity
questions.correctAnswer: A technique to evaluate model performance on multiple data splits
questions.explanation: Cross-validation splits the data into multiple folds, training and testing the model on different combinations to get reliable performance estimates.

title: Supervised Learning Algorithms
description: Deep dive into popular supervised learning algorithms and their applications.

questions.question: What is the key difference between linear regression and logistic regression?
options: Linear regression is for classification, logistic for regression
Logistic regression outputs probabilities, linear regression outputs continuous values
Linear regression uses sigmoid activation, logistic doesn't
Logistic regression is only for binary classification
questions.correctAnswer: Logistic regression outputs probabilities, linear regression outputs continuous values
questions.explanation: Linear regression predicts continuous numerical values, while logistic regression predicts probabilities for classification tasks.

questions.question: What is the main advantage of Support Vector Machines (SVM)?
options: They are very fast to train
They work well with high-dimensional data
They can handle missing values automatically
questions.correctAnswer: They work well with high-dimensional data
questions.explanation: SVMs are effective in high-dimensional spaces and can handle non-linear classification using kernel functions.

questions.question: What does 'k' represent in k-Nearest Neighbors algorithm?
options: The number of nearest neighbors to consider
questions.correctAnswer: The number of nearest neighbors to consider
questions.explanation: k-NN classifies a data point by looking at the k closest training examples and using majority voting.

questions.question: What is bagging in ensemble methods?
options: Training multiple models on random subsets of data
Using only the best performing models
questions.correctAnswer: Training multiple models on random subsets of data
questions.explanation: Bagging (Bootstrap Aggregating) creates multiple models by training on random subsets of the training data.

questions.question: What is boosting in ensemble learning?
options: Training models sequentially where each model corrects the previous one's errors
questions.correctAnswer: Training models sequentially where each model corrects the previous one's errors
questions.explanation: Boosting trains models sequentially, with each new model focusing on correcting the mistakes of the previous models.

questions.question: What is the main difference between Random Forest and Gradient Boosting?
options: Random Forest uses bagging, Gradient Boosting uses boosting
Random Forest is for regression only
questions.correctAnswer: Both A and C
questions.explanation: Random Forest uses bagging (parallel models), while Gradient Boosting uses boosting (sequential models), and Gradient Boosting typically requires more hyperparameter tuning.

questions.question: What is XGBoost?
questions.correctAnswer: An optimized gradient boosting library
questions.explanation: XGBoost is an optimized implementation of gradient boosting that includes regularization and parallel processing for better performance.

questions.question: What is the 'curse of dimensionality'?
options: When there are too many features relative to samples
When data has too many categories
questions.correctAnswer: When there are too many features relative to samples
questions.explanation: The curse of dimensionality refers to problems that arise when working with high-dimensional data, where the volume of the space increases exponentially.

title: Unsupervised Learning
description: Explore clustering, dimensionality reduction, and other unsupervised techniques.

questions.question: What is the elbow method used for in k-means clustering?
options: Choosing the optimal number of clusters
questions.correctAnswer: Choosing the optimal number of clusters
questions.explanation: The elbow method plots the within-cluster sum of squares against the number of clusters, looking for an 'elbow' point where adding more clusters doesn't significantly improve the fit.

questions.question: What is hierarchical clustering?
options: Building a hierarchy of clusters using agglomerative or divisive approaches
questions.correctAnswer: Building a hierarchy of clusters using agglomerative or divisive approaches
questions.explanation: Hierarchical clustering creates a tree-like structure of clusters, either by starting with individual points and merging (agglomerative) or starting with one cluster and splitting (divisive).

questions.question: What is DBSCAN?
questions.correctAnswer: A density-based clustering algorithm
questions.explanation: DBSCAN (Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise) groups together points that are closely packed, marking points in low-density regions as outliers.

questions.question: What does PCA do?
questions.correctAnswer: Reduces dimensionality while preserving variance
questions.explanation: PCA finds principal components that capture the maximum variance in the data, allowing dimensionality reduction while preserving as much information as possible.

questions.question: What is t-SNE used for?
questions.correctAnswer: Visualizing high-dimensional data in 2D or 3D
questions.explanation: t-SNE (t-Distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding) is a dimensionality reduction technique specifically designed for visualizing high-dimensional data.

questions.question: What is the silhouette score used for?
questions.correctAnswer: Evaluating clustering quality
questions.explanation: The silhouette score measures how similar an object is to its own cluster compared to other clusters, providing a measure of clustering quality.

questions.question: What is anomaly detection?
questions.correctAnswer: Identifying unusual or suspicious cases
questions.explanation: Anomaly detection identifies data points that deviate significantly from the normal behavior or expected patterns in the dataset.

questions.question: What is the main difference between supervised and unsupervised learning?
options: Supervised learning requires labeled data, unsupervised learning doesn't
Supervised learning is only for classification
questions.correctAnswer: Supervised learning requires labeled data, unsupervised learning doesn't
questions.explanation: Supervised learning algorithms learn from labeled training data, while unsupervised learning algorithms find patterns in unlabeled data.

title: Neural Networks & Deep Learning
description: Advanced concepts in neural networks, architectures, and training techniques.

questions.question: What is a perceptron?
options: The basic building block of neural networks
questions.correctAnswer: The basic building block of neural networks
questions.explanation: A perceptron is a single-layer neural network unit that takes multiple inputs, applies weights and bias, and produces a binary output.

questions.question: What is the vanishing gradient problem?
options: When gradients become too small during backpropagation
When the learning rate is too high
When the loss function is not convex
questions.correctAnswer: When gradients become too small during backpropagation
questions.explanation: The vanishing gradient problem occurs in deep networks when gradients become exponentially small during backpropagation, preventing weight updates in earlier layers.

questions.question: What does LSTM stand for?
questions.correctAnswer: Long Short-Term Memory
questions.explanation: LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) is a type of recurrent neural network designed to remember information for long periods, solving the vanishing gradient problem.

questions.question: What is transfer learning?
options: Using pre-trained models for new tasks
questions.correctAnswer: Using pre-trained models for new tasks
questions.explanation: Transfer learning leverages knowledge from pre-trained models on large datasets to improve performance on related tasks with smaller datasets.

questions.question: What is dropout in neural networks?
options: A regularization technique that randomly drops neurons during training
A method to reduce network size
questions.correctAnswer: A regularization technique that randomly drops neurons during training
questions.explanation: Dropout randomly deactivates neurons during training to prevent overfitting by forcing the network to learn redundant representations.

questions.question: What is a convolutional layer in CNNs?
options: A layer that performs matrix multiplication
A layer that applies convolutional filters to detect patterns
questions.correctAnswer: A layer that applies convolutional filters to detect patterns
questions.explanation: Convolutional layers apply learnable filters to input data, detecting local patterns and features in images or sequences.

questions.question: What is the purpose of pooling layers in CNNs?
options: To reduce spatial dimensions and computational complexity
questions.correctAnswer: To reduce spatial dimensions and computational complexity
questions.explanation: Pooling layers (like max pooling) reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps, making the network more computationally efficient and providing translational invariance.

questions.question: What is reinforcement learning?
options: Learning through trial and error with rewards
questions.correctAnswer: Learning through trial and error with rewards
questions.explanation: Reinforcement learning involves agents learning optimal behavior through interactions with an environment, receiving rewards or penalties for actions.

title: Natural Language Processing
description: Explore text processing, language models, and NLP applications.

questions.question: What is tokenization in NLP?
options: Breaking text into smaller units like words or sentences
questions.correctAnswer: Breaking text into smaller units like words or sentences
questions.explanation: Tokenization splits text into tokens (words, phrases, or characters) that can be processed by NLP models.

questions.question: What is word embedding?
options: Representing words as dense vectors in continuous space
questions.correctAnswer: Representing words as dense vectors in continuous space
questions.explanation: Word embeddings represent words as dense vectors where semantically similar words have similar vector representations.

questions.question: What is TF-IDF?
options: A statistical measure of word importance in documents
questions.correctAnswer: A statistical measure of word importance in documents
questions.explanation: TF-IDF (Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency) measures how important a word is to a document in a collection, balancing term frequency with document frequency.

questions.question: What does BERT stand for?
questions.correctAnswer: Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers
questions.explanation: BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers) is a transformer-based model that understands context from both directions in text.

questions.question: What is sentiment analysis?
options: Determining the emotional tone of text
questions.correctAnswer: Determining the emotional tone of text
questions.explanation: Sentiment analysis determines whether text expresses positive, negative, or neutral sentiment.

questions.question: What is named entity recognition (NER)?
options: Extracting structured information from unstructured text
questions.correctAnswer: Extracting structured information from unstructured text
questions.explanation: NER identifies and classifies named entities like persons, organizations, locations, dates, etc., from text.

questions.question: What is the attention mechanism in transformers?
options: A way to focus on important parts of the input
A method to reduce model size
questions.correctAnswer: A way to focus on important parts of the input
questions.explanation: The attention mechanism allows models to focus on relevant parts of the input sequence when making predictions, improving context understanding.

questions.question: What is text preprocessing in NLP?
options: Cleaning and preparing text data for analysis
questions.correctAnswer: Cleaning and preparing text data for analysis
questions.explanation: Text preprocessing includes tasks like removing punctuation, stop words, stemming, lemmatization, and normalization to prepare text for NLP models.

title: Computer Vision
description: Learn about image processing, object detection, and visual recognition.

questions.question: What is image classification?
questions.correctAnswer: Assigning labels to entire images
questions.explanation: Image classification assigns predefined labels or categories to entire images based on their visual content.

questions.question: What is object detection?
options: Locating and classifying objects within images
questions.correctAnswer: Locating and classifying objects within images
questions.explanation: Object detection identifies and locates multiple objects in an image, providing both classification and bounding box coordinates.

questions.question: What is semantic segmentation?
questions.correctAnswer: Classifying pixels into categories
questions.explanation: Semantic segmentation assigns each pixel in an image to a class or category, providing detailed understanding of image content.

questions.question: What is a region proposal network (RPN) in object detection?
options: A network that proposes regions likely to contain objects
questions.correctAnswer: A network that proposes regions likely to contain objects
questions.explanation: RPN generates potential object bounding boxes (region proposals) that are then classified and refined by the detection network.

questions.question: What is the IoU (Intersection over Union) metric?
options: A metric for evaluating object detection accuracy
questions.correctAnswer: A metric for evaluating object detection accuracy
questions.explanation: IoU measures the overlap between predicted and ground truth bounding boxes, used to evaluate object detection performance.

questions.question: What is data augmentation in computer vision?
options: Creating synthetic training images through transformations
questions.correctAnswer: Both A and B
questions.explanation: Data augmentation artificially increases dataset size and diversity by applying transformations like rotation, flipping, scaling, and color changes to existing images.

questions.question: What is transfer learning in computer vision?
options: Using pre-trained models on new vision tasks
questions.correctAnswer: Using pre-trained models on new vision tasks
questions.explanation: Transfer learning applies knowledge from models trained on large datasets (like ImageNet) to new, smaller vision tasks.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a fully connected layer in CNNs?
questions.correctAnswer: Combining features for final classification
questions.explanation: Fully connected layers combine features learned by convolutional layers to make final predictions or classifications.

title: Model Deployment & Production
description: Learn about deploying ML models to production environments.

questions.question: What is model serialization?
options: Converting models to a format that can be saved and loaded
questions.correctAnswer: Converting models to a format that can be saved and loaded
questions.explanation: Model serialization converts trained models into a format (like pickle, joblib, or ONNX) that can be saved to disk and loaded later.

questions.question: What is A/B testing in ML deployment?
options: Testing model performance on new data
questions.correctAnswer: Comparing two different models
questions.explanation: A/B testing compares two versions of a model (or system) by serving them to different user groups and measuring performance metrics.

questions.question: What is model monitoring?
questions.correctAnswer: Monitoring model performance in production
questions.explanation: Model monitoring tracks key metrics like accuracy, latency, and data drift to ensure models perform well in production environments.

questions.question: What is containerization in ML deployment?
options: Packaging models and dependencies in containers
questions.correctAnswer: Packaging models and dependencies in containers
questions.explanation: Containerization packages ML models with their dependencies and runtime environment, ensuring consistent deployment across different systems.

questions.question: What is MLOps?
options: A type of machine learning algorithm
Practices for deploying and maintaining ML systems in production
questions.correctAnswer: Practices for deploying and maintaining ML systems in production
questions.explanation: MLOps combines ML, DevOps, and data engineering practices to standardize and streamline ML lifecycle management.

questions.question: What is model versioning?
options: Tracking different versions of trained models
questions.correctAnswer: Tracking different versions of trained models
questions.explanation: Model versioning tracks different iterations of trained models, allowing rollback to previous versions and comparison of performance.

questions.question: What is feature drift?
options: When model features change over time
questions.correctAnswer: When input data distribution changes
questions.explanation: Feature drift (or data drift) occurs when the statistical properties of input features change over time, potentially degrading model performance.

questions.question: What is REST API in the context of ML deployment?
options: A standard for building web services to serve ML predictions
questions.correctAnswer: A standard for building web services to serve ML predictions
questions.explanation: REST APIs provide a standardized way to expose ML models as web services, allowing applications to send data and receive predictions via HTTP requests.

title: Ethics & Bias in AI
description: Understand ethical considerations, bias detection, and responsible AI practices.

questions.question: What is algorithmic bias?
options: When AI systems produce unfair outcomes for different groups
When models overfit the training data
When algorithms require too much data
questions.correctAnswer: When AI systems produce unfair outcomes for different groups
questions.explanation: Algorithmic bias occurs when AI systems systematically disadvantage certain groups due to biased training data or flawed algorithms.

questions.question: What is model interpretability?
options: How fast a model makes predictions
How well humans can understand model decisions
questions.correctAnswer: How well humans can understand model decisions
questions.explanation: Model interpretability refers to the ability to understand and explain how a model makes predictions, which is crucial for trust and accountability.

questions.question: What is data privacy in AI?
options: Protecting individuals' personal information in AI systems
questions.correctAnswer: All of the above
questions.explanation: Data privacy in AI encompasses protecting personal information, ensuring proper data handling, and complying with privacy regulations like GDPR.

questions.question: What is fairness in machine learning?
options: Ensuring AI systems don't discriminate against protected groups
Making models as accurate as possible
questions.correctAnswer: Ensuring AI systems don't discriminate against protected groups
questions.explanation: Fairness in ML involves designing systems that don't systematically disadvantage certain demographic groups and ensuring equitable treatment.

questions.question: What are the potential risks of black-box AI models?
options: They are slower than other models
They cannot be understood or audited by humans
questions.correctAnswer: They cannot be understood or audited by humans
questions.explanation: Black-box models lack interpretability, making it difficult to understand decision-making processes, debug issues, or ensure ethical behavior.

questions.question: What is AI safety?
options: Preventing AI systems from harming humans
Ensuring AI systems are secure from hacking
questions.correctAnswer: All of the above
questions.explanation: AI safety encompasses preventing harm, ensuring robustness, maintaining security, and aligning AI systems with human values.

questions.question: What is the purpose of bias detection tools?
options: To identify and mitigate unfair treatment in AI systems
questions.correctAnswer: To identify and mitigate unfair treatment in AI systems
questions.explanation: Bias detection tools help identify discriminatory patterns in AI systems, allowing developers to address fairness issues before deployment.

questions.question: What is responsible AI development?
options: Considering ethical, social, and technical implications throughout AI lifecycle
questions.correctAnswer: Considering ethical, social, and technical implications throughout AI lifecycle
questions.explanation: Responsible AI development involves ethical considerations, fairness, transparency, accountability, and societal impact throughout the entire AI development process.

title: Time Series Analysis
description: Learn about time series data, forecasting, and temporal pattern recognition.

questions.question: What is a time series?
options: A series of data points indexed in time order
questions.correctAnswer: A series of data points indexed in time order
questions.explanation: A time series is a sequence of data points collected or recorded at regular time intervals, showing how a variable changes over time.

questions.question: What is stationarity in time series?
options: When data points are evenly spaced
When statistical properties remain constant over time
When the series has no trends or seasonality
questions.correctAnswer: Both B and C
questions.explanation: A stationary time series has constant statistical properties (mean, variance) over time and no systematic trends or seasonal patterns.

questions.question: What is ARIMA?
options: AutoRegressive Integrated Moving Average - a forecasting method
questions.correctAnswer: AutoRegressive Integrated Moving Average - a forecasting method
questions.explanation: ARIMA is a popular statistical method for time series forecasting that combines autoregression, differencing, and moving averages.

questions.question: What is seasonality in time series?
options: Regular patterns that repeat over fixed periods
questions.correctAnswer: Regular patterns that repeat over fixed periods
questions.explanation: Seasonality refers to predictable, recurring patterns in time series data that occur at regular intervals, like daily, weekly, or yearly cycles.

questions.question: What is autocorrelation?
options: The correlation between different time series
The correlation of a time series with its own past values
The correlation between predicted and actual values
questions.correctAnswer: The correlation of a time series with its own past values
questions.explanation: Autocorrelation measures how correlated a time series is with its own past values, helping identify patterns and dependencies.

questions.question: What is exponential smoothing?
options: A method to reduce data size
A forecasting technique that gives more weight to recent observations
A way to handle missing values
questions.correctAnswer: A forecasting technique that gives more weight to recent observations
questions.explanation: Exponential smoothing assigns exponentially decreasing weights to past observations, giving more importance to recent data for forecasting.

questions.question: What are LSTM networks commonly used for?
options: Time series prediction and sequence modeling
questions.correctAnswer: Both B and C
questions.explanation: LSTM networks excel at modeling sequential data, making them ideal for time series forecasting, language modeling, and other sequence prediction tasks.

questions.question: What is cross-validation in time series?
options: Using rolling forecast origin for validation
questions.correctAnswer: Using rolling forecast origin for validation
questions.explanation: Time series cross-validation uses techniques like rolling forecast origin to maintain temporal order and avoid data leakage.

title: Optimization & Hyperparameter Tuning
description: Master model optimization, hyperparameter tuning, and performance improvement techniques.

questions.question: What are hyperparameters?
options: The output of a trained model
questions.correctAnswer: Configuration settings set before training
questions.explanation: Hyperparameters are external configuration settings that control the learning process and must be set before training begins.

questions.question: What is grid search?
options: An exhaustive search over specified hyperparameter values
A way to reduce model complexity
questions.correctAnswer: An exhaustive search over specified hyperparameter values
questions.explanation: Grid search systematically tries all combinations of hyperparameter values from specified lists to find the optimal configuration.

questions.question: What is random search?
questions.correctAnswer: Randomly sampling hyperparameter combinations
questions.explanation: Random search samples random combinations of hyperparameters from specified distributions, often more efficient than grid search.

questions.question: What is Bayesian optimization?
options: Using Bayesian statistics for model training
A probabilistic approach to hyperparameter tuning
A method for Bayesian network construction
questions.correctAnswer: A probabilistic approach to hyperparameter tuning
questions.explanation: Bayesian optimization uses probabilistic models to predict which hyperparameter combinations will perform well, efficiently exploring the search space.

questions.question: What is early stopping?
options: Stopping training when validation performance starts to degrade
Stopping training after a fixed number of epochs
Stopping training when training loss becomes zero
questions.correctAnswer: Stopping training when validation performance starts to degrade
questions.explanation: Early stopping monitors validation performance and stops training when it begins to worsen, preventing overfitting.

questions.question: What is learning rate scheduling?
options: Changing the learning rate during training
Scheduling when to update model weights
questions.correctAnswer: Changing the learning rate during training
questions.explanation: Learning rate scheduling adjusts the learning rate during training, often starting high and decreasing over time for better convergence.

questions.question: What is regularization?
questions.correctAnswer: Adding penalties to prevent overfitting
questions.explanation: Regularization adds penalty terms to the loss function to discourage complex models and prevent overfitting.

questions.question: What is model pruning?
options: Removing unnecessary parts of a trained model
questions.correctAnswer: Removing unnecessary parts of a trained model
questions.explanation: Model pruning removes redundant weights or neurons from trained models to reduce size and computational requirements while maintaining performance.
